Have you ever travelled on a train? Have you ever walked into a park? Have you ever chewed gum?
Now you must be wondering that why does one need to focus and concentrate on chewing a pack of gum, walking in a park or maybe travelling on the train?
I'm sure by the end of this article you will stop scratching your head and will have a different eye towards life.
Do not dwell in the past, do not dream of the future, concentrate the mind on the present moment.

The above saying was preached by Gautam Buddha who was also once asked about the practice that he and his monks followed. To which his answer was simple but enlightening. His words were "we sit, we walk and we eat". He was further asked, "everyone sits, walks and eats, what is new on your part?"
The Buddha was attributing to living fully in the present moment to the fullest with Mindfulness.

Mindfulness is an ancient Buddhist practice which is very relevant for our lives today. It means paying attention: in a particular way, on purpose, in the present moment, and non-judgementally. It is a practical way to notice thoughts, physical sensations, sight, smell, sounds, anything that would not come into our notice otherwise. In simple words, it is choosing and learning to control our focus of attention.
http://localhost:3001/images/quonquer_images/a3/a3_02.png
Definition: Mindfulness

1. Mindfulness of something: There has to be something to be mindful about. Your breathing, steps and some other areas of the body can usually be a point of focus. Concentration and Mindfulness work hand in hand. concentration, on one hand, is focusing on a single point of contact while practising mindfulness on the other is to develop your power of concentration along with developing your power of being Mindful. One cannot separate Mindfulness and Concentration.

2. Mindfulness of something in the present moment: The point of focus of Mindfulness is always in the present, it does not focus on the past or future but it doesn’t necessarily have to be something existing in the physical world. If your attention is not on something which exists in the present moment, you are not being mindful as you are making a conscious decision of focusing on your past, future or some other imaginable moment.                                               Often people think of Mindfulness as simply just observing things on a surface level. You might think you’re observing the surrounding, but in reality, you are observing your perception of those things. Mindfulness is going beyond that overt observation and internalizing what you have observed so that you can overcome your wrong perceptions and get to the reality with no filters.

3. A conscious decision: Mindfulness is directing your consciousness to the present, for a purpose. It is like an anchor point to the present moment. Imagine mindfulness as a ship and yourself as a Captain. You will consciously decide, where to place the anchor. Next, you throw the anchor, i.e. your concentration, off the ship. The anchor then reaches the intended anchor point, where it will rest. Initially, the anchor will not be strong but eventually, it will become tough and resilient enough.

4. Nonjudgmental awareness: Mindfulness accepts everything around our vision in its original form and this is the utmost purpose of mindfulness. True peace and happiness can be found from mindfulness because it is completely non-judgmental. It just requires you to be mindful of all the things that you observe and expects you to make no distinctions, hold no bias and is free of the mental filters that distort our perception of what is real. It enables us to experience true reality liberally.

5. Developed with time: In the beginning, your mindfulness energy will be weak but over time your mindfulness will become strong and you’ll be able to differentiate between your ability to concentrate and the ability to see things with Mindfulness. It will take practice to master the “art of being Mindful” and trying to fit the practice of mindfulness in your life will conflict with your existing habits. It’s called “Habit energy” in Buddhism. Each activity we do has a certain energy and the more you do something the more energy it builds.

6. Enabling the HD mode in your life: Once people develop the “Art of Mindfulness”, it feels as if one has enabled the High Definition mode of life. When you make the conscious decision of being Mindful is when you wake up from your half-awakened state. It will lead you to notice things that remained unnoticed before and it will magnify details of life.                Mindfulness is a single thing, it is non-judgmental, Point of focus is in the present, the decision of being aware in the present reality is conscious. This enables us to look at the world with novelty and it is beyond our incorrect perceptions, existing notions, deep-seated emotions, and beyond the ego. Seeing reality with purity and without any filter with unlimited joy and happiness.

Imagine your field of mindfulness wrapping up everything within your perception and now imagine a thin ray of light emerging from your mindfulness field directing towards a single point of contact. This thin ray of light is your concentration whereas Mindfulness is a gentle awareness. It is Mindfulness that is active when your concentration becomes passive and your thoughts wander and It is completely non-judgmental.
Initially, being mindful will appear and feel like this:
a) Focus on your breath
b) lose focus and sometimes become aware of the thought or feeling that came to your mind
c) back to focusing on your breathing
But after practising you will start to notice these thoughts and feelings more often and with more clarity and that will eventually lead you to acknowledge them with mindfulness.

Practising Mindfulness It takes practice for every individual to master the task that they do. Be it any profession, for example- A cricketer, no matter how successful he is, will not just go for a match without practising his play. He needs to practice to master the existing skills or to develop new skills. Simply repeating the skills will benefit him in strengthening the core or basic skills, for example, working on the line, length and at the same time keeping his space in control serves as the core skills for a bowler.

Similarly, when it comes to Mindfulness, the core or basic skills include that of sitting meditation which is the most fundamental and traditional way of meditation. Thus, to begin with, if a person sits and meditates even for 5 minutes at any chosen time of the day will help you kick start the practice of Mindfulness.
How to practice Mindful sitting? There are 3 steps to get into successful Mindful sitting.
1. Sit
2. Breathe
3. Be Mindful
a) Find a place that has no disturbances. It can be indoors or outdoors depending on the comfort of the person.

b) Find the sitting position that gives utmost comfort to you. It could be sitting on the floor in Half Lotus or Full Lotus position or sitting on a chair/couch. If required you can also use a cushion to provide additional comfort or stability.

c) Once sitting comfortably, you can now relax and take a few deep breaths and allow yourself to adjust to that new position. d) Your neck and back should be straight and stomach should be relaxed at the same time. A correct posture ensures correct meditation with correct breathing and concentration.

e) Place the fingers of your one hand over the fingers of the other and simultaneously touch the tips of your thumbs, making an oval shape. The logic behind sitting in cosmic mudra has a meaning but in short, it helps you bring your mind, body and breath together.
f) Begin with looking down and allow your eyelids to drop naturally. Keeping your eyes half-closed prevents inviting lethargy and a sleepy state of mind and it also prevents blinking often.
http://localhost:3001/images/quonquer_images/a3/a3_04.png

a) Close your mouth and inhale followed by exhaling. Simply observe the act that we do 24/7, focus on the breath that goes in and goes out. Do not try to restrict or exert yourself through deep breathing. Just breathe normally and direct your concentration towards it. Initially, you might find it difficult to concentrate but to keep the focus solely on breathing should be the primary goal.

b) Count each breath that goes in as one and each breath that goes out till two. Count till 10 and if you get distracted in the middle then simply start over your counting from one. Repeat this for a few months till it this task becomes effortless.

c) Thoughts are automatic and one cannot put complete control on them. You can try to change your thoughts but you cannot put a full stop to it. For that matter, even to change a particular thought, you need to give attention to those thoughts which merely means to acknowledge them. Our mind is a wanderer and it is bound to get distracted as in such a fast-paced life we do not involve ourselves to remove time for self and thus when we sit to be mindful, we will have a million thoughts running over our head. The task is not to ignore or filter any thoughts but to simply acknowledge it, notice it and let it pass.

d) Let the thought come, greet it and let it go. Request your mind to get back to its original business of focusing on breathing. This will be a task and will be frustrating until you practice it. Your mind will be the best guide and will do what it is supposed to once it learns to drift from your thoughts to your breathing.

Not all emotions can be put into words, similarly, mindfulness is not something that can be learnt overnight. Nevertheless, with practice, it can be achieved and applied to anything and everything, like mindful walking, eating, driving, and a lot more.
